title: How to Make Chili Con Carne

methods.name: Making Quick and Simple Chili Con Carne

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat for about 1 to 2 minutes.
steps.description: The oil needs to be hot before you can add the onion and garlic.

steps.headline: Add the garlic and onion and cook until the onion softens.
steps.description: This will take about 2 to 3 minutes. Still, the onion and garlic often with a wooden spoon or spatula so that they don't burn.

steps.headline: Add the ground beef and cook until the beef has browned.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon or spatula to help break the beef up into smaller pieces, and flip the beef occasionally so that both sides cook. Pour the excess fat away; you can save this fat for another recipe, or you can throw it into the trash.

steps.headline: Add the beans, tomato sauce, chili powder, and salt.
steps.description: Do not drain the beans before adding them; simply toss everything into the skillet. The liquid from the beans will help keep the chili moist and prevent it from becoming too dry.

steps.headline: Simmer over low heat until the chili turns thick.
steps.description: This can take as little as 30 to 40 minutes to as long as 2 hours.

steps.headline: Garnish the chili, if desired, then serve it.
steps.description: You can always serve the chili as it, but it will be much tastier with some cilantro, shredded cheese, or sour cream.

methods.name: Making Chili Con Carne with Beans

steps.headline: Heat the oil in a large skillet over medium heat, then add the onions, and cook them until they turn soft.
steps.description: Add the oil into the skillet, then heat it over medium heat. Once the oil starts to sizzle, add the onion, and cook it until it turns after, about 1 to 2 minutes. Stir the onions occasionally with a wooden spoon or spatula so that they don't burn.

steps.headline: Add the garlic, red pepper, chili powder, paprika, and ground cumin, and cook for another 5 minutes.
steps.description: Stir the mixture occasionally to help them cook evenly.

steps.headline: Turn the heat up to medium-high heat, add the meat, and cook it for another 5 minutes or so.
steps.description: Use a wooden spoon or spatula to break the meat up, and then to stir it. This will help it cook evenly.

steps.headline: Crumble 1 beef stock cube into 1¼ cups (300 milliliters) of hot water, then add it to the skillet.
steps.description: Pour the hot water into a large cup or saucepan, then crumble the beef stock cube into it. Stir the water and stock to combine, then pour it into the skillet. Stir everything together once more.

steps.headline: Add the diced tomatoes, marjoram, sugar, some salt and pepper, and the tomato paste.
steps.description: For a more authentic twist, replace the sugar with a small piece of dark chocolate. The chocolate should be about the size of your thumbnail. You want just enough to sweeten the chili, but not so much that you can taste it.

steps.headline: Bring the mixture to a boil, then simmer it for 20 minutes over low heat.
steps.description: Keep the skillet covered while it is simmering. Check the skillet occasionally, and give the chili a stir to prevent the sauce from scorching. If the chili starts to dry, add a few tablespoons of water.

steps.headline: Drain the beans, add them to the skillet, and cook the chili uncovered for 10 minutes.
steps.description: It is important to drain the beans; if you don't, the chili will be too soggy and soupy. You can still the mixture from time to time if you'd like, to help distribute the flavors better.

steps.headline: Let the chili stand for 10 minutes before serving to let the flavors infuse.
steps.description: Keep the lid on the pot so that the chili doesn't cool off too much.

steps.headline: Serve the chili.
steps.description: You can serve it as is, or over some rice. You can also garnish it with sour cream, crumbled tortilla chips, or shredded cheese.

methods.name: Making Chili Con Carne without Beans

steps.headline: Toast the cumin seeds until they turn fragrant.
steps.description: Place a large skillet on the stove and set the heat to medium-high. Add the cumin seed, and toast them until they turn fragrant, about 1 minute.

steps.headline: Crush the cumin seeds, then take them out of the skillet and set them aside.
steps.description: You can crush them using a smaller pan, or a flat-bottomed metal or wooden tool. Remove the seeds when you are done, and set them aside.

steps.headline: Cook the bacon in the skillet until it turns crispy, then set it aside but save the drippings.
steps.description: Put the bacon into the same skillet you used to toast the cumin seeds. Cook the bacon over medium-high heat until it turns crispy. Once it is done, set the bacon aside on top of some folded paper towels, but leave the drippings in the skillet.

steps.headline: Brown the beef in the bacon drippings over high heat then set the beef aside and leave the drippings in the pan.
steps.description: You will be using the bacon and beef drippings to cook the rest of the ingredients.

steps.headline: Sauté the onion in the drippings over medium heat, then add the spices and sauté for 1 minute more.
steps.description: Reduce the heat to medium, then add the chopped onion. Sauté it until it turns brown, about 8 to 10 minutes. Then, add the toasted cumin seeds, chili powder, paprika, oregano, black pepper, thyme, salt, and minced garlic. Sauté for 1 minute more, stirring occasionally.

steps.headline: Add the bacon, beef, garlic, beef broth, tomatoes, ancho chilies, and water.
steps.description: Crumble the bacon first, then add it to the skillet. Add in the rest of the ingredients, and give the chili a stir to mix everything in.

steps.headline: Bring the chili to a boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer, and cook partially covered for 2 hours.
steps.description: Add more water as necessary to keep the chili from drying out. You can also cook this in a slow cooker for 6 to 8 hours.

steps.headline: Take out the ancho chilies, purée them in a blender, then stir them back into the chili.
steps.description: Using a slotted spoon or fork, scoop out the ancho chilies, and purée them in a blender. Add the puréed chilies back into the skillet, and give everything a good stir.

steps.headline: Serve the chili.
steps.description: You can serve it as is, or you can garnish it with some chopped onions, shredded cheese, or crumbled saltine crackers. This recipe also goes well with tamales or rice.
